ml:doc-envelope.ml:original-txt:
38195 THE DOMINICANREPUBLIC
ProgrammaticPower Sector Reform Loan (Loan 7292-DO) Release of the FirstTranche andRequest for One Waiver
Tranche Release Document
1. The Bank approved a Programmatic Power Sector Reform Loan (PPSRL) o f US$l50 million for the Dominican Republic on May 10,2005 (Report No. 31741-DO o f April 12, 2005). The PPSRL has yet to be declared effective due to the reversal o f a number o f prior conditions to Board presentation. All prior conditions have now been metwith the exception of one for which we seek awaiver.
2. The PPSRL supports the initial phase of the Government's strategy for the financial recovery o f the power sector to stabilize electricity supply, by improving cash recovery, controlling costs and dealing with arrears. The PPSRL i s part o f a program o f assistance to the energy sector to assist the Government during the transition period towards the financial recovery o f the sector to reestablish regular electricity services, and restore trust among investors. It will assist the Government inthe provision o f declining subsidies while strengthening the management o f the distribution companies to reduce losses and improve collection by stabilizing power supply, and enforcing payment discipline among consumers.
3. The PPSRL i s designed to be disbursed inthree tranches. The first tranche will be disbursed at effectiveness, while the second and third floating tranches will be released when the corresponding conditions are met. Although the Government initially met the conditions prior to presentation o f PPSRL to our Board in May 2005, it took over six months for the Loan Agreement to be presented to Congress and ratified. During this period andinthe following months, the Government began to accumulate arrears with the private generation companies inviolation o f one of the prior conditions, and decided not to apply the formula for the automatic adjustment o f retail tariffs for variations in exchange rate, fuel price and inflation, thereby violating another prior condition. The Government recently cleared its arrears with the generation companies, and i s currently providing compensatory measures in lieu o f the tariff adjustment to ensure that the financial sustainability o f the distribution and generation companies will not be affected. Inthe last few months, the fiscal situationdeteriorated, puttingat risk the macroeconomic framework going forward; however a package o f revenue and expenditure measures for 2006 and 2007 was recently agreed with the IMF under its Stand-By Arrangement (SBA), which should put the country back into a sustainable debt path and satisfactory macroeconomic framework.
4. The following sections o f this memorandum summarize the progress in implementing the reform program supported by the PPRSL.
5. Overall, implementation o f the policies supported by the PPSRL has shown progress inreaching the objectives o f this program, despite the political difficulties o f the Government, the dramatic increase inthe internationalprice o f oil, and the difficulties o f
- 1 -  reversing the culture o f non payment o f electricity bills by consumers. Arrears with the generation companies have now been settled and the only unmet condition relates to the application of the formula for the automatic adjustment o f retail tariffs for variations in exchange rate, fuel price and inflation. The Government i s providing compensatory resources to the sector to ensure that the financial viability o f the distribution and generation companies will not be affected by the corresponding shortfall inrevenues.
6. Going forward, the Government has developed a comprehensive plan for the sector to improve service quality and toughen sanctions for the theft o f electricity. As part o f this plan and o f the combined 5th and 6th review o f the Stand-By Arrangement with the IMF, the Government is committed to allow electricity tariffs to fluctuate inline with the automatic adjustment formula. Incase electricity tariffs were temporarily lower thanthereference tariffs, the Government will cover any additionaltransfers to the sector by reducing non-priority spending. The Government also expects to complete a review o f the tariff structure by June 2007, aimed at reducing incentives to commit electricity fraud and at channeling subsidies to low-income households.
7. Based on the overall implementation o f the program, and in view of the recent improved performance o f the distribution companies (see below) and progress in the implementation o f a comprehensive program for the recovery o f the sector, a waiver i s proposed for the following condition: "revision and implementation of aformula for the automatic adjustment of retail tarvfs for variations in exchange rate, fuel prices and inflation". Upon Board approval o f this proposal, the Bank would advise the Borrower that the loan i s declared effective andthat the first tranche i s available for withdrawal.
I. RecentEconomicPerformanceandProspects
8. Inthe aftermath of the banking and macroeconomic crisis of 2003 and 2004, the Dominican economy experienced a booming recovery in 2005 when it posted real GDP growth o f 9.3 percent. Continued strong growth during the first three quarters o f this year suggests an annual real growth rate o f at least 10 percent for 2006. Economic stability has improved markedly during this period. Inflation returned to single digits in 2005 and 2006 fi-om average annual rates o f 27 and 51 percent in 2003 and 2004, respectively, and the exchange rate stabilized to about RD$30/US$ in 2005 compared to RD$49/US$ in early 2004 (the peso is currently trading at RD$33/US$). Imports and FDIhave largely recovered since the crisis. Whereas gross international reserves were severely depleted during the 2003-04 macroeconomic crisis, dipping below US$300 million, the subsequent steady build-up has led to reserve levels o f US$2.3 billion currently, providing a reasonable cushion for the Central Bank. Banking sector deposits andcredit to the private sector have been increasing since end-2004, and interest rates for both lending and deposits have declined dramatically. Risk spreads on international bonds have also fallen sharply, from highs o f around 1,100 basis points in2003 to current levels of 200-250 basis points.
9. The strong growth performance in2005 and 2006 contributed to lower debt ratios (also aided by key debt restructurings by the Paris and London Clubs), and two tax
- 2 -  reforms coupledwith the introduction o f expenditure controls andbetter budgetprocesses led to a marked improvement in the fiscal balance, from an overall NFPS deficit o f 3.6 percent o f GDP in 2004 to near balance in 2005 (-0.4 percent o f GDP). Nevertheless, fiscal pressures remained in2006, particularly due to the highenergy sector subsidies and lower-than-anticipated revenues from the 2005 tax reforms and the foreign exchange commission, leading to a 2006 projected overall NFPS fiscal deficit considerably larger thanthe zero balance originally programmedunder the IMF Stand-By Arrangement. To address this slippage, the authorities agreed to expenditure restraint for the remainder o f 2006 in order to achieve a 0.8 percent deficit, and have agreed with the IMF on a tax reform package estimated to yield 1.5 percent o f GDP (beginningin2007). Furthermore, the authorities are drafting a 2007 budget (in consultation with the IMF and to be submitted to Congress in the coming weeks) that is consistent with the IMF program target o f a 2007 primary surplus equal to 2.2 percent o f GDP.
10. Looking ahead, the prospects for sustained GDP growth and maintaining macroeconomic stability are good. Several institutional reform measures currently pending Congressional approval will strengthen budget controls and thus solidify progress on the fiscal front, and the forthcoming entry into effectiveness o f the free trade agreement between the Dominican Republic, U S and Central American countries - DR- CAFTA - will boost export demand and increase imports from the US, to the benefit o f consumers and producers (albeit with an expected decline in tariff revenue). The Government intends to request an eight-month extension (through January 2008) o f the IMF Stand-By Arrangement to support the implementation of its economic program during2007.
11. The Power Sector ReformProgram
11. The actions supported by the PPSRL aim at initiating the financial recovery o f the sector to stabilize power supply, by improving cash recovery, controlling costs and dealing with arrears.
12. The implementation o f the PPSRL program has been satisfactory, particularly in the recent months when the distribution companies started to obtain tangible results in terms o f loss reduction and collection improvement. As mentioned above, although the Government initially met the sectoral conditions prior to presentation o f the PPSRL to our Board in May 2005 (see Table 1 below), subsequently the Government decided to discontinue the applicationo f the formula for the automatic adjustment o f retail tariffs for variations in exchange rate, fuel price and inflation, thereby violating a prior condition. The Government however i s providing compensatory measures to ensure that the financial sustainability o f the distribution and generation companies will not be affected.
- 3 -  Table 1- Summary of Status o f the Conditions for FirstTranche Release
FirstTranche Conditions Summaryof Present Status andProgress Maintenance o f a satisfactory Achieved macroeconomic framework A viable and binding agreement between Achieved the Government and 15 out of 18 operators to record arrears in the electricity sector, schedule payment of interest and provide one year moratorium on debt repayment Government has remain current on its electricity bills and has transferred Achieved budgetary funds via CDEEE to the distribution companies, in accordance with the Power Sector RecoveryPlan Plans for the financial recovery o f the sector approved and implementation started, including:
a) Plans o f the Distribution companies to Achieved reduce losses and improve collection while controlling costs; and b) Cash Recovery Index o f the distribution companies combined (cumulative over six months) increased from 45 percent in Aurmst 2004 to 50 Dercent Revision and implementation o f a formula Not achieved, but budgetary compensatory for the automatic adjustment o f retail tariffs measures allocated to ensure the provision for variations in exchange rate, fuel prices o f corresponding additional revenues to the and inflation distributioncomDanies Formulation o f a contingency plan in case Achieved performance o f the nationalized distribution companies does not improve simificantlv Creation o f a Crisis Committee to oversee Achieved the implementation o f the financial recovery plan, and appointment o f its coordinator Launch o f a communication campaign to Achieved build sumort for the recoveryplan
- 4 -  13. Progress has been slow in the first year of the program implementation due to political factors, including the minority representation o f the Government in the lower house of the Congress and the presence o f only one representative out o f thirty-one inthe Senate. However, a number o f steps were taken to change the management of the state- owned utilities and prepare for an aggressive loss reduction campaign. Private sector management with international experience was contracted by the Government to lead EdeSur and EdeNorte, two o f the three distribution companies. The third distribution company, EdeEste whose majority shareholding is private, also changed its top management to ensure more focused attention on theft reduction, particularly by large consumers. Outsourcing to private contractors in the two utilities to detect theft, and increase billing and collectionwas undertaken. Support from the Government interms o f more personnel and resources to the Office o f Consumer Protection (PROTECOM) who accompany the utilities to certify connection irregularities was also provided. Inaddition, power supply was stabilized at about 80-85 percent o f demand. However, in 2005, overall subsidy requirements topped US$600M (2.1% o f GDP), due to the increase inthe international oil prices (fuel oil price escalated from US$21.8/bbl in January 2005 to US$42.6/bbl in December 2005), and the lower than expected performance (though still positive) of the distribution companies interms of loss reductionandbill collection.
14. Since May 2006, results have started to become more visible. The Cash Recovery Index - which measures the percentage o f power purchases paid for by consumers - has improved from 51.7% in May 2006 to 53.8% in September 2006. Recently the Government has also re-launched a communication campaign against theft of electricity. During a stakeholders meeting held last September, it was concluded that some legislative changes to facilitate the anti theft campaign by the distribution companies were needed. Under the leadership o f the Government through the ComisidnNacional de Energia, the distribution companies have formulated the proposed amendments to the Law to criminalize theft and establish special courts to prosecute those stealing electricity. The proposed amendments will be presented shortly to the Congress.
15. After adjusting electricity tariffs to reflect the variations in international petroleum prices, in February 2006 the Government decided to freeze them. This was because electricity tariffs in the Dominican Republic are extremely high (at around US$0.22/kWh), and a further increase would have resulted in larger non-payment o f electricity bills and therefore counteracted the ongoing efforts made by the distribution companies to increase collection.
16. Inthe next few months, the Government will continue to facilitate the anti theft campaign by the distribution companies and require tangible results. Monitoring will be assured by the Comisidn Nacional de Enevgia (the agency in charge o f energy policy) together with the Supevintendencia de Electricidad (the regulatory body), and the CDEEE. Other steps that the Government plansto implement inthe short term include:
0 defining and implementinga nationalantitheft strategy;
- 5 -  removing remaining legal and regulatory barriers to facilitate the loss reduction programby the distribution companies; expanding the communication strategy focused on anti theft; providingadequate financial resources for investment indistribution; implementingprograms to improve collectionand service; designing and implementing a new tariff structure and measurement of quality o f service; and defining a package to protect and facilitate access by the poor, including tariffs, and service.
17. Through these measures, a reduction inthe losses and an improvement inthe bill collection by the distribution companies are expected to be accelerated, thereby improving the financial performance o f the sector and the reliability o f power supply. The resulting improvement in the quality o f power supply would in turn create more favorable conditions for the Government to adjust tariffs in line with variations in fuel prices.
18. Inlight of the above and despite the original delays in effectiveness, the overall program, as well as the conditions spelled out for second and third tranches, i s still achievable.
- 6 -

doc.repnme: Dominican Republic - Programmatic Power Sector Reform Loan - release of the first tranche : waiver of one condition
doc.abstracts: The programmatic power sector reform loan for Dominican Republic is designed to be disbursed in three tranches. The first tranche will be disbursed at effectiveness, while the second and third floating tranches will be released when the corresponding conditions are met. Although the Government initially met the conditions prior to presentation of PPSRL to our Board in May 2005, it took over six months for the Loan Agreement to be presented to Congress and ratified. During this period and in the following months, the Government began to accumulate arrears with the private generation companies in violation of one of the prior conditions, and decided not to apply the formula for the automatic adjustment of retail tariffs for variations in exchange rate, fuel price and inflation, thereby violating another prior condition. The Government recently cleared its arrears with the generation companies, and is currently providing compensatory measures in lieu of the tariff adjustment to ensure that the financial sustainability of the distribution and generation companies will not be affected. In the last few months, the fiscal situation deteriorated, putting at risk the macroeconomic framework going forward; however a package of revenue and expenditure measures for 2006 and 2007 was recently agreed with the IMF under its Stand-By Arrangement (SBA), which should put the country back into a sustainable debt path and satisfactory macroeconomic framework.
